text: Aporosa planchoniana is a species of shrub in the family Phyllanthaceae. ==Taxonomy and etymology== A. planchonianaappears to be in a clade with sisters A. ficifolia, A. octandra var. octandra, A. tetragona and A. villosa, separated from other species within the section Appendiculatae. Common names include miën préi (="wild longan", Khmer) and propech chongva (Kuy/Khmer). ==Description== The species grows 2-4m tall, occurring in open forests. It is found in Thailand, Myanmar, Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam. It has been erroneously recorded as occurring in South-Central and Southeast Zhōngguó/China, including Hainan. At Khao Yai National Park, central Thailand, the orange dehiscent fruit grow some 9mm long, 7 mm in diameter and weighing just 0.3g. There is one seed per fruit, weighing 0.05g, 6mm long and 4mm in diameter. The fruit has been observed to be consumed by Bulbuls and squirrels (Callosciurus finlaysonii and Ratufa bicolor). ==Distribution and habitat== The shrub grows on the leeward side of the Bang Boet coastal sand dune, Pak Klong sub-district, Pathio District, Chumphon Province, southern Thailand (facing east into the Gulf of Thailand. ==Utilization== The fruit is edible and the stems are used as firewood. Amongst Kuy- and Khmer-speaking people living in the same villages in Stung Treng and Preah Vihear provinces of north-central Cambodia, the small tree is used as source of medicine. ==References== planchoniana Category:Flora of Cambodia Category:Flora of Laos Category:Flora of Myanmar Category:Flora of Thailand Category:Flora of Vietnam Category:Plants described in 1858 Category:Taxa named by Johannes Müller Argoviensis Category:Taxa named by Henri Ernest Baillon
title: Aporosa planchoniana
